items.title: The subtle seed of Arrogance
items.author: Selena Bright
items.content:
Notice, Smile, and Let Go, so I can truly beÂ FREE

Somewhere inside every success story you have, thereâ€™s a little seed of arrogance quietly waiting for you to noticeÂ it.

If Iâ€™m honest, Iâ€™m not immune to itÂ either.

Back in high school, I once won First Prize in a city-wide Literature contest. My family and I were over the moon. But right at that moment when my name was called, I felt something strange rise up inside me. I was happy, yes, but there was also this littleâ€¦ â€œIâ€™m specialâ€ kind of pride. I remember thinking: â€œSo, I guess I really am better than a lot of people.â€ Looking back, I can still picture my smile that day. Only one word:Â proud.

But not exactly innocentÂ anymore.

Later on, when I started getting invited to speak at my old company events and share with other colleagues, that feeling came back. Every time I stepped on stage, heard the applause, saw the admiration in peopleâ€™s eyesâ€¦ something inside me inflated. If I told you I was completely humble back then, Iâ€™d be lying. Part of me really did feel â€œaboveâ€ the audience, like I was someoneÂ special.

And I know that feeling is dangerous.

It swept me away, made me forget that I was just a regular person sharing my experiences, not some guru sent to enlighten theÂ masses.

Maybe youâ€™ve felt this too. After getting a high grade, receiving a compliment, or enjoying a little spotlight on social media,â€¦ you feel on top of the worldâ€¦ and then you want more. Thatâ€™s when it becomes a trap. The more you crave recognition, the more you fear losing it: fear of being outshined, fear of fallingÂ behind.

As students, arrogance sneaks in quietly. Sometimes itâ€™s as simple as comparing test scores. One person gets B+, another gets A, and suddenly the A feels â€œaboveâ€ the B+. But that happiness is short-lived, because the next second, they see someone with A+ and feel small again. Arrogance always comes with comparison. It canâ€™t stand alone. It only exists when we put ourselves on a scale next to others. Thatâ€™s why arrogance is never satisfied. The more you feed it, the hungrier and more fragile itÂ becomes.

How about todayâ€™s social media? Itâ€™s like a giant magnifying glass for arrogance. A photo that gets a lot of likes, a story full of compliments, a small achievement shared widelyâ€¦ all become fuel for the ego. You start feeling â€œdifferent,â€ â€œspecial,â€ and then you feel trapped by that image youâ€™ve created. You stop living for yourself and start living to protect the glow others see in you. You forget that learning, working, creating are supposed to be joyful in themselves, not just proof that youâ€™re better than someoneÂ else.

If you look a little deeper, youâ€™ll see arrogance is just a mask for fear. People brag because theyâ€™re afraid of being ignored. They compare because theyâ€™re scared of being leftÂ behind.

Arrogance isnâ€™t strength. Itâ€™s a defense mechanism.

Itâ€™s like wearing shiny armor so everyone is dazzled by you, but inside, your heart is trembling, terrified that one day the shine willÂ fade.

But what ifâ€¦ when you scored well, instead of thinking â€œIâ€™m better than them,â€ you simply smiled because your hard work paid off? What ifâ€¦ when you got praised online, instead of pressuring yourself to stay perfect, you just thought, â€œIâ€™m glad this resonated with someoneâ€? What ifâ€¦ when you were chosen as team leader, you saw it as a chance to learn to listen, not a chance to show power? Success would suddenly feel lighter, purer, no longer weighed down by arrogance.

For me, the hardest part isnâ€™t killing arrogance. Itâ€™s daring to notice it. The next time I catch myself comparing or feeling smug, I definitely donâ€™t push it away. Just smile and whisper to myself: â€œAh, Iâ€™m being arrogant right now.â€ Just noticing it weakens its grip. Arrogance thrives in the dark, when we donâ€™t see it. The moment we see it clearly, weâ€™ve already taken one step out of itsÂ trap.

Some people ask: if Iâ€™m not arrogant, will I become insecure? I think itâ€™s the opposite. When you let go of arrogance, you become truly confident. You can say â€œI donâ€™t knowâ€ without shame. You can fail without feeling worthless. You can praise others without feeling small. Thatâ€™s real strength: the thing that doesnâ€™t rely on applause toÂ exist.

Life as a young mom (aka student aka worker) is already stressful enough: duties, exams, deadlines, family expectations, endless comparisons. I donâ€™t need the heavy mask of arrogance on top of that. Life becomes so much lighter when I take it off. A genuine talk with a friend. Sharing my struggles without fear of judgment. Walking under the evening sky and feeling small in a beautiful way. These moments only open up when I stop trying to prove myself and allow myself to just be a regular person, not above, not below anyoneÂ else.

Think of arrogance like a balloon. The more you pump it up with praise and recognition, the bigger and higher it floats, but the easier it is to pop. One tiny needle and boom, emptiness. But if from the start, you can hold it gently in your hand, play with it, but not depend on it. You wonâ€™t fear losingÂ it.

Iâ€™m reminded of a story: a student pours tea for a teacher, and keeps pouring until the cup overflows. The teacher smiles and says, â€œThe cup is full. How can anything more be poured in?â€ Arrogance is just like that. It fills your mind until thereâ€™s no space left for new lessons, new experiences, or even the wisdom that failure can bring. Only when we stay humbleâ€”admitting we donâ€™t know everything, we arenâ€™t perfectâ€Šâ€”â€Šcan life keep pouring fresh flavors intoÂ us.

We donâ€™t need to prove we are better than anyone. Study, work, create for the joy of it, not for someoneâ€™s approval. Let your success be like a wildflower growing quietly by the road, fragrant, but not desperate to be seen. And if one day you catch yourself feeling arrogant, just smile, acknowledge it, and let itÂ go.

So your heart can stayÂ open.

Because maybe the greatest freedom isnâ€™t standing above others, but no longer needing to. Being simply yourselfâ€”calm, unpretentious, without comparisonâ€Šâ€”â€Šis already a beautiful gift. And when you reach that point, youâ€™ll see: arrogance never truly made you happy, but letting it go justÂ might.

items.title: How I Built a Product Dashboard with ReactJS, Spring Boot, and PostgreSQL
items.author: Selena Bright
items.content:
From end toÂ end

A few months ago, I decided to challenge myself with a fullstack project: a Product Management Dashboard.

I wanted something practical: an app where I could manage products and brands, with features like filtering, creating, editing, and viewing details. At the same time, I wanted to sharpen my skills after taking a career break, and building something from scratch felt like the best way to doÂ that.

For the stack, I chose ReactJS for the frontend, Spring Boot for the backend, and PostgreSQL for the database. Together, they gave me a solid foundation to explore modern web development and practice building a complete application from end toÂ end.

You can clone this project via GithubÂ here.

Project Architecture ğŸ—ï¸

When I started this project, my goal was to keep the architecture simple but clearâ€Šâ€”â€Šcovering the full flow from database â†’ backend â†’ frontend â†’ deployment.

Database DesignÂ ğŸ—„ï¸

The application has two main entities:

  • Brand (e.g., Apple, Samsung,Â Xiaomi)
  • Product (belongs to a Brand, e.g., iPhone 14, GalaxyÂ S22)
  • User (e.g admin, user1,Â user2)

The relationship is many-to-one: many products can belong to one brand.
I designed threeÂ tables:

brands: id, name, country, founded_year, website, description, created_at, updated_at, deleted

products: id, name, brand_id (FK), quantity, price, created_at, updated_at, deleted

users: id, username, password, role, created_at, updated_at, deleted

Backendâ€Šâ€”â€ŠSpring BootÂ âš™ï¸

The backend is built with Java Spring Boot and includes:

  • Spring Data JPA for ORM and databaseÂ access.
  • Spring Security with JWT for authentication and protecting APIs.
  • REST APIs for CRUD operations on Products andÂ Brands.
  • Filtering API to query products by name, brand, minPrice, and maxPrice.
  • CSV Data Initialization: seed database with products and brands from a CSV file on firstÂ run.
  • AWS Secrets Manager to securely fetch and manage database credentials and secretÂ keys.
  • Testing:
    Unit tests for service layer business logic.
    Integration tests for REST APIs, verifying end-to-end flows with the database.

Example endpoint:

GET /api/products?brand=Apple&minPrice=500

returns all Apple products priced aboveÂ $500.

Frontendâ€Šâ€”â€ŠReactJSÂ ğŸ¨

The frontend is a ReactJS dashboard with:

  • Table view to list products.
  • Filter form (brand, price range,Â name).
  • Modal forms to create, edit and delete products.
  • Statistics chart (using Chart.js/Recharts) to visualize the number of products perÂ brand.
  • State management using React hooks (useState, useEffect).

The UI is kept simple, focusing on usability and responsiveness.

AWSâ€Šâ€”â€ŠCloudÂ â˜ï¸

The project also integrates with AWS services forÂ secure:

  • AWS Secrets Manager to securely store and retrieve database credentials and JWT secret keys for authentication.
  • CloudFormation to define infrastructure as code, ensuring reproducible environments.
  • IAM for fine-grained accessÂ control.

This approach keeps sensitive information out of the codebase and makes the application easier to deploy in production environments.

Deployment â˜ï¸

  • Backend: deployed onÂ Render.
  • Frontend: deployed onÂ Render.
  • Database: PostgreSQL hosted onÂ Neon.

Whenever I push code to GitHub, Render automatically rebuild and deploy the updatedÂ app.

ğŸ‘‰ In short, the project architecture looks likeÂ this:

PostgreSQL (Neon) â†â†’ Spring Boot APIs â†â†’ ReactJS Dashboard â†â†’Â Render

Building this Fullstack Product Dashboard gave me hands-on experience with ReactJS, Spring Boot, PostgreSQL, and AWS. From designing REST APIs and securing them with JWT, to implementing a responsive dashboard and integrating cloud secrets management, this project reflects how a modern fullstack app can be built end-to-end.

items.title: Balancing Code and Life
items.author: Selena Bright
items.content:
A journey back to programming

Hi. Iâ€™m a young Asian mom, trying to raise my child while learning something new everyÂ day.

Iâ€™ve been away from programming for quite a while, long enough to forget almost everything I onceÂ knew.

Nearly twoÂ years.

During that time, while I was busy holding my baby close, the Earth kept spinning, people kept building, and countless new tools and technologies came to life. With the crazy rise of machine learning, I sometimes feel like a villager suddenly dropped into the bigÂ city.

Everything feelsÂ new.

So new that itâ€™sÂ scary.

I sit at my desk, staring at the laptop screen, hands falling limp, not knowing where to startÂ again.

I open my GitHub account, scroll through old projects, make a cup of tea, glance out the window, andÂ thinkâ€¦

What was I doing before I decided to cut off all screen time two yearsÂ ago?

I was building websites, landing pages, and mobileÂ apps.

And what programming languages was I using backÂ then?

Dart. Java. HTML.Â CSS.

But now, everywhere I look, itâ€™s all aboutÂ AI.

Should I switch to machine learning?

I laugh at my own sillyÂ thought.

Getting a job is my top priority. Time waits for no one. While others are earning money every second, would I waste hundreds of hours chasing after a hot trend? Starting all over again from zero? That would beÂ madness.

So Iâ€™ll return to what I already have a foundation in.

Java, or Dart? I only have time to go deep into one ofÂ them.

Java has a huge global market share. More than 90% of Fortune 500 companies still use it, not to mention its powerful ecosystem. Dart, on the other hand, is growing fast, but the community is stillÂ small.

High market share and a strong community mean more job opportunities, but also tougher competition. Still, I made myÂ choice.

Iâ€™ll focus onÂ Java.

One hour of theory can never compare to one hour of practice. I started building a simple web application: a product management dashboard for an electronics store.

At first, it only had basic CRUD features: create, delete, update products. Later, I added a simple chart to show product statistics byÂ brand.

After more than 2 weeks of learning and practicing side by side, I deployed the dashboard on Render. You can check it outÂ here.

(The server may go to sleep if it hasnâ€™t been used for a while. If the login page freezes, just wait 2 minutes and refresh theÂ page.)

At the beginning, I struggled to balance child care, learning, and still getting enough rest. But after finishing this little project, I picked up some lessons on time managementÂ , along with two small reminders I want to write down here, mostly to remindÂ myself.

1. Sleep at night isÂ crucial

In the first three days, I forced myself to wake up at 5 am while going to bed at 1 am. That gave me more than 4 hours to study every day, and I thought it was effective, until my body gaveÂ up.

Completely. Gave.Â Up.

I couldnâ€™t keep my eyes open. I was moody. My head was foggy. I craved sugar likeÂ crazy.

Daytime already takes so much energy: cleaning, cooking, going to the market, taking care of my childâ€¦ After 9 pm, I still sat down to study until 1 am. This endless cycle of activity with no rest was simplyÂ foolish.

So I changed my routine: still waking up at 5 am, but going to bed at 11 pmÂ instead.

My daily plan had adjusted:

  • 30 minutes of yogaÂ daily.
  • During my childâ€™s nap, I rest at least 20 minutes instead of rushing to theÂ market.
  • Cut down market trips to just twice aÂ week.
  • Take my child out to play more often so he gets tired and falls asleepÂ earlier.
  • Put him to bed one hourÂ earlier.
  • Shortened my study time from 4 hours to 3Â hours.

With these small changes, my sleep went from 4 hours to 6 hours at night, plus a 30-minute nap. My energy returned. I stopped craving sugar. My mind became clearer. And my study efficiency actually wentÂ up.

A good sign, isnâ€™t it?Â ^_^

2. 100% focus whileÂ studying

Time is precious, especially when you have a lot to get done in one day. Sometimes my to-do list feels endless, and it distracts me while Iâ€™m learning.

Coding while thinking about tomorrowâ€™s zoo trip makes me want to open another tab and search â€œbest things to see at ABCÂ Zoo.â€

Coding while worrying about not getting emails from recruiters makes me want to stop and fix my resumeÂ instead.

Soâ€¦ Donâ€™t think about anythingÂ else.

Focus. 100%. On. What. Iâ€™m.Â Doing.

A cup of tea helps. Coffee works too. Even dark chocolate is fine. But never RedÂ Bull.

Turn on a favorite playlist. Or keep the room silent. Sometimes just the sound of ocean waves is enough to pull me back intoÂ focus.

Thatâ€™s it. Just two simpleÂ things.

Remember them well,Â me.
